newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Israel court tells army to recognise same-sex spouse.
newsitem.headline: Israel court tells army to recognise same-sex spouse.

text.p: An Israeli district court in a landmark decision on Friday ordered the army to recognise a gay man as the spouse of a deceased male colonel and extend him the same benefits as military widows, a spokesman said.
"The appeals committee decided it would recognise Adir Steiner as an army widower and grant him the according rights," court spokesman Moshe Gorali told Reuters.
Survivors of deceased army personnel are entitled to a monthly pension, tax deductions and other benefits.
"This is the first time the state is required to recognise a man as the spouse of a man," Steiner told Reuters. "It is the first time in my life I feel as an equal Israeli citizen."
Steiner, 30, had appealed against a 1995 court decision declaring him ineligible for survivor benefits after his longtime companion Colonel Doron Maisel died of cancer in 1991.
"This is a historic and revolutionary decision," Steiner's lawyer Amnon Ben Dror said, adding "It requires the state -- not only a private company -- to pay spousal benefits to a same-sex companion."
Israel's Supreme Court in 1994 ordered Israel's El Al airline to extend the same benefits to same-sex partners of gay employees as it did to heterosexuals.
Ben Dror said the decision could set a precedent not only for the army but also for the police force and other government bodies. "It could end up costing the state millions," he said.

Steiner, a media consultant, said he petitioned for survivor benefits because the army had accepted him as Maisel's partner while he was alive. He said Maisel, a medical officer, was open about his homosexuality and was promoted over the years by officers who knew he was gay.
The decision comes on the heels of a public storm last month over Israeli President Ezer Weizman's derision of homosexuality as "abnormal".
Weizman, whose presidential role is largely symbolic, later met with Steiner and other gay activists to express sorrow for the remarks.
